page.title: 01Introduction to the area
page.content: The block is bounded to the west by a well-used road and the edge of the R.A.C. Tank Training area. To the east lies Wareham Forest with Forestry Commission conifer plantations. Mostly low-lying between streams, it is rural in character. The lanes are narrow and the population sparse and scattered among farms and small dwellings with a few larger houses and new bungalows. Grassland supports dairy farmers, with some cereal and fruit growing. Some small businesses, a gravel extraction firm and a market garden are the only industries. A golf-club, a priately owned Youth Activity centre offer leisure pursuits. There is an animal sanctuary, a nature reserve and a site of special scientific interest. Natural growth includes heathland, bog, meadows, scrub and woodland. There is a small Methodist Chapel.
